Volatile organic compounds (VOCs), such as toluene, have aroused wide concerns its emissions growth and harmfulness. Catalytic oxidation has been considered as one of the most efficient technologies for toluene degradation. In this work, MOF-derived CeO2 supported Ag catalysts were prepared by different synthesis method. Toluene oxidation test found that Ag-Ce-BTC-C synthesized by one-pot and calcination at 500 °C under Ar and O2 atmosphere exhibited the better catalytic performance for toluene oxidation (T90 = 226 °C). H2 temperature programmed reduction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic results exhibited that the preparation method had a great influence on the physicochemical properties of the supported Ag catalysts. The better catalytic performance was attributed to the better reducibility, more active oxygen species and oxygen vacancies, higher molar ratio of Oads/Olat, Ce3+/Ce4+ and Ag0/Agδ+. This work has a certain guiding significance for the preparation of highly active MOF-derived supported catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MOF derivatives Ag catalysts Toluene oxidation Synthesis method 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs), such as toluene, have aroused wide concerns its emissions growth and harmfulness. It has been proved that VOCs are the dominant precursor of ozone and smog formation [1,2]. Thus, it is urgent for the removal of VOCs. Recently, many technologies, such as photocatalysis [3–5], advanced oxidation [6], plasma catalytic [7], adsorption [8,9], and catalytic oxidation [10–13], have been employed for the elimination of VOCs. Among the numerous removal technologies, catalytic oxidation, as one of the most efficient technologies, has been extensively used due to its low energy consumption, simple operation and no secondary pollution [14,15]. However, the key factor is to find an efficient catalyst for the elimination of VOCs. For the catalytic oxidation of VOCs, the catalysts can be divided into two kinds, noble metal catalysts and metal oxidation. The noble metal catalysts including Pt-, Pd-, Au-based catalysts, due to their excellent catalytic performance have been widely studied [16–18]. However, the scarcity of these noble metal cannot satisfy the requirement for catalysts, limiting their application for catalytic oxidation. In addition, the aggregation of noble metal catalysts during preparation and reaction is another shortcoming for their application. Metal oxide, such as MnOx [15], CeO2 [19], CoOx [20] and some other metal oxide [21–23], have been widely studied for catalytic oxidation. However, compared with noble metal catalysts, the catalytic performance of metal oxide is inferior. Thus, supported noble metal catalysts can be a great choice. The supported noble metal catalysts also have been extensively researched [24–26]. For example, Li et al. [26] prepared polyhedral cobalt oxide supported Pt nanoparticles for toluene, which exhibited excellent catalytic performance and stability. Li et al. [27] prepared Pd/TiO2 catalyst impregnation method for formaldehyde oxidation, which could oxidize HCHO to H2O and CO2 at ambient temperature. And Chen et al. [28] prepared Au-doped α-MnO2 catalyst by a novel redox precipitation and used for formaldehyde. Compared with α-MnO2, the introduction of Au greatly improved the catalytic performance of formaldehyde. However, the preparation of these Pt-, Pd-, and Au-based catalysts is not economical in the comparison to Ag, another low-cost noble metal. Recently, the supported Ag catalysts have also received widely attention. For Ag-based catalysts, the catalytic activity is closely to the supports. Thus, it is important to seek a suitable support for a high reactivity Ag-base catalysts. CeO2, as a common rare earth metal oxide, is extensively employed as a support. And it exhibits great redox properties and large oxygen storage capacity. There have been reported many preparation methods for the synthesis of CeO2, such as hydrothermal [29], redox reaction [30], sol-gel [31], precipitation [30] and sacrificial MOF-template method [32]. Among these synthesis methods, the CeO2 prepared by sacrificial MOF-template method exhibits excellent catalytic activity for VOCs oxidation [33]. Generally speaking, Ce-MOF were divided into Ce-BTC and Ce-BDC. Sun et al. [34] prepared CeO2 by in situ pyrolysis of Ce-MOFs (Ce-BTC and Ce-BDC) for toluene oxidation, and found that the CeO2 synthesized by in situ pyrolysis of Ce-BTC exhibited better catalytic performance than that of Ce-BDC for toluene oxidation. Additionally, Xi et al. [32] prepared CeO2 by in situ pyrolysis of Ce-MOF (Ce-BTC). Compared with CeO2 prepared by precipitation and the commercial CeO2, the CeO2 prepared by in situ pyrolysis of Ce-BTC exhibited good catalytic performance. However, since the catalytic reaction occurs at the solid/gas interface, the introduction of a low-cost noble metal on the surface of metal oxides can greatly improve their reactivity [35]. Li et al. [26] prepared polyhedral cobalt oxide supported Pt nanoparticles. Compared with the Co3O4 prepared by precipitation method and the polyhedral CoOx prepared by the pyrolysis of ZIF-67, the polyhedral CoOx supported Pt nanoparticles catalyst exhibited a better catalytic activity. In addition, our group [36] had been prepared Ag/Fe2O3 by the pyrolysis of MIL-100(Fe). Compared with Fe2O3, the catalytic performance of Ag/Fe2O3 for CO oxidation improved greatly. However, although these metal oxides supported with noble metals exhibited better catalytic performance than metal oxides, the effect of synthesis processes on the structure and reactivity of supported noble metal catalysts have not been considered. For support noble metal catalysts, there are many synthesis methods, such as one-pot method, precipitation, impregnation and so on. For impregnation, it had been reported that impregnation synthesis and post-synthesis impregnation will greatly affect the catalytic activity of the supported catalyst [37]. In addition, our previous work found that post-assembly methods (impregnation) and in-situ incorporation methods (one-pot method) could also affect the catalytic performance of Ag/HMS for CO oxidation [38]. Thus, in this work, the CeO2 supported Ag catalysts were prepared by different method. A series characterization results indicated that the preparation methods had a great influence on the reducibility, active oxygen species, surface oxygen vacancies, surface chemical composite and state. These physicochemical properties were further affected the catalytic performance of the catalysts. The influence of preparation methods on the physicochemical properties and catalytic activity of the supported Ag catalysts was discussed in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All the chemicals were analytic reagent and directly used. Cerous(Ⅲ) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3•6H2O, 99.0%), silver nitrate (AgNO3, 99.8%), 1,3, 5-phthalic acid (H3-BTC, 98%), absolute ethanol (99.7%) and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5%) were bought from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalysts synthesis 2.2.1 Preparation of Ce-BTC The Ce-BTC was prepared by solvothermal method (Scheme 1(A)) followed by our previous works [39,40]. Typically, 0.01 mol of Ce(NO3)3•6H2O and 0.006 mol of H3-BTC were placed in 60 mL of DMF and stirred vigorously for 30 min until completely dissolved. Then, the clarified solution was transferred into stainless steel reactor and crystallized at 130 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the pale-yellow powder could be got by centrifuging, washing and drying. 2.2.2 Preparation of CeO2–500 The CeO2–500 was prepared by pyrolysis of Ce-BTC (Scheme 1(B)). 1.0 g of as-prepared Ce-BTC was placed in a U-type quartz reaction tube at a fixed bed reactor with an open tube furnace. Firstly, the furnace was heated from room temperature to 500 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min and maintained for 2 h to carbonize the Ce-BTC under Ar flow. After cooling to room temperature, the carbonized sample was treated at 500 °C for another 2 h under 30% O2/Ar flow to obtain the cerium oxide. The obtained light-yellow powder was named as CeO2–500. 2.2.3 Preparation of Ag/CeO2-IM and Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C The supported Ag catalyst was prepared by wet impregnation method according our previous work [36]. For Ag/CeO2-IM (Scheme 1(B)), the prepared CeO2–500 was impregnated with AgNO3 solution, and dried at room temperature for 12 h, then transferred to an oven and dried at 70 °C overnight. Finally, the catalyst named as Ag/CeO2-IM could be obtained by pretreating under 30% O2/Ar at 500 °C for 2 h. For Ag/Ce-BTC-IM (Scheme 1(C)), the prepared Ce-BTC was impregnated with AgNO3 solution, and dried at room temperature for 12 h, then transferred to an oven and dried at 70 °C overnight. Finally, the Ag/Ce-BTC-IM was first treated at 500 °C for 2 h under Ar flow and then treated at 500 °C for another 2 h under 30% O2/Ar flow. The synthesized catalyst was named as Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C. The theoretical loading of Ag in Ag/CeO2-IM and Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C was 4 wt%. 2.2.4 Preparation of Ag-Ce-BTC-C The Ag-Ce-BTC was prepared by a one-pot solvothermal method (Scheme 1(D)). During the preparation of Ce-BTC, a certain amount of AgNO3 solution was added into the clarified solution and stirring for 30 min. Then, the above solution was transferred into stainless steel reactor and crystallized at 130 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the catalyst named as Ag-Ce-BTC could be got by centrifuging, washing and drying. For Ag-Ce-BTC-C, the as-prepared Ag-Ce-BTC was firstly treated at 500 °C for 2 h under Ar flow and then treated at 500 °C for another 2 h under 30% O2/Ar flow. The synthesized catalyst was named as Ag-Ce-BTC-C. The theoretical loading of Ag in Ag-Ce-BTC-C was 4 wt%. 2.3 Catalysts characterization A Bruker D8 Advanced X-ray diffractometer was used to measure the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-prepared samples. The thermogravimetry (TG) curves was obtained from synchronous thermal analyzer (PerkinElmer, STA8000) under the air atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 30 °C to 800 °C. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was performed on the Nicolet iS50 (Thermo Fisher, America) with the resolution ratio of 4 cm−1 and scan times of 64. The N2 adsorption and desorption used to measure the pore properties of the samples was carried out on a Quantachrome autosorb-iQ-2MP apparatus under 77 K (the temperature of liquid nitrogen). Before analysis, the samples were outgassed under vacuum at 105 °C for 12 h to remove impurities. The specific surface area and pore size distribution were calculated by the Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) and model Barrett Joyner Halenda (BJH) method, respectively. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was carried out on ICP-OES730 (Agilent). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out on Gemini SEM 300. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy were performed on TECNAI G2 F20 instrument. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were performed on a UV–vis spectrometer (UV-2600, Shimadzu, Japan) using BaSO4 as the internal standard. The H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on ChemBET TPR/TPD, which was used to determine the reduction properties. The reduction atmosphere was 10 vol% H2/Ar. The temperature was heated from 50 °C to 900 °C with 10 °C/min heating rate. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) was used to measure the surface chemical states and composition of the samples, and the results were obtained on ESCALAB Xi+ (Thermo Fisher, America). The binding energies of C 1 s at 284.8 eV was used for charge correction 2.4 Catalysts performance Toluene was selected to evaluate the catalytic performance of the synthesized catalysts. A fixed-bed reactor equipped with an open tube furnace was used to the oxidation of toluene under normal pressure. The reaction gas contained 1000 ppm of toluene was introduced to the reaction system. Typically, 100 mg of catalyst (20–40 mesh) was placed into a quartz tube. The gas flow rate was set to 50 mL/min (weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) = 30,000 mL/(g•h)) and controlled by a mass flow controller. At every temperature, it should be stabilized for 30 min before testing and the data reported at each reaction temperature was the average of three measurements. The GC2060 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with flame ionization detector was used for online analysis of inlet and outlet gas. The following formula was used to calculated the conversion of toluene: X = ( C T 0 − − C T ) / C T 0 × 100 % where X, CT0 and CT were toluene conversion, toluene concentration of the influent and the effluent gas, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The XRD patterns of Ce-BTC, CeO2–500 and the supported Ag catalysts are displayed in Fig. 1 . It can be found from Fig. 1(A) that the XRD pattern of Ce-BTC was in keeping with our reported works [41], indicating the successfully synthesis of Ce-BTC. After calcination, the characteristic peak of Ce-BTC disappeared and some new peaks appeared. As shown in Fig. 1(B), the diffraction peaks of 2θ at 28.5°, 33.0°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.4°, 76.7°, and 79.1° are contributed to the (111), (200), (311), (222), (400), (331) and (420) lattice planes of CeO2 (JCPDS 34–0394), respectively. After the introduction of Ag, two new peaks appeared at 38.1° and 44.3° are ascribed to the (111) and (200) lattice planes of Ag (JCPDS 04–0783), respectively, indicating the successfully introduction of Ag nanoparticles (NPs). Notably, no peaks of Ag and Ag2O can be found in Ag/CeO2-IM, which may be ascribed to the high dispersion of Ag NPs. The crystal size of CeO2 of CeO2–500 and the supported Ag catalysts were calculated by Scherrer formula and the results are summarized in Table 1 . The crystal of CeO2–500, Ag/CeO2-IM, Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C and Ag-Ce-BTC-C are 25.6, 24.2, 28.8, 21.8 nm, respectively. In addition, no peaks shift of CeO2 could be found in all the supported Ag catalysts, indicating that the introduction of Ag had no influence to the crystal of CeO2. Fig. 2 shows the TG curves of Ce-BTC and Ag-Ce-BTC-C. For Ce-BTC, the weightlessness can be divided into three stages. The minimum weight loss below 102 °C is attributed to the loss of physically adsorbed and lattice coordinated water molecule. The second stage between 102 and 265 °C is ascribed to the loss of organic solvent DMF and the water in the pores of Ce-BTC. The third stage between 265 and 380 °C is due to the decomposition of organic ligand and oxidation, causing the collapses of crystal structure and forming cerium oxide [42]. After calcination at 500 °C, the Ag-Ce-BTC-C presents almost no weight loss, indicating no residual C in Ag-Ce-BTC-C. Fig. 3 shows the FT-IR spectra of Ce-BTC, CeO2 and the supported Ag catalysts. It can be found that after calculation, the peaks attributed to the organic ligand of Ce-BTC were disappeared, indicating the Ce-BTC is decomposed to CeO2. This is consistent with XRD result. In addition, compared with CeO2–500, no significant difference can be found in the supported Ag catalysts, indicating that the introduction of Ag had no influence to the crystal of CeO2. To learn the specific surface area and pore size of the samples, the N2 adsorption-desorption was used, and the results are displayed in Fig. 4 . All the curves show a type IV pattern with an H3 hysteresis loop, indicating that all the catalysts are mesoporous materials [43, 44] The BET specific surface area, total pore volume and the pore diameter of CeO2–500 and the supported Ag catalysts are summarized in Table 1. The BET specific surface area of CeO2–500, Ag/CeO2-IM, Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C and Ag-Ce-BTC-C are 53.6, 45.0, 17.6 and 35.9 m2/g, respectively. After the introduction of Ag NPs, the BET specific surface area is decreased, which is attributed to that the Ag NPs were successfully supported on CeO2 and occupied or blocked the pores [17]. Fig. 4(B) shows the pore distribution of CeO2–500 and the supported Ag catalysts calculated by BJH method. It can be found that the introduction of Ag NPs has no significant influence on the pore structure of the samples. The total pore volume of CeO2–500, Ag/CeO2-IM, Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C and Ag-Ce-BTC-C is 0.118, 0.095, 0.076 and 0.152 cc/g, respectively Obviously, compared with CeO2–500 and other supported Ag catalysts, Ag-Ce-BTC-C possesses the largest pore volume (0.152 cc/g), which may be ascribed to that AgNO3 entered the pore of Ce-BTC during the preparation process. After calcination at 500 °C, the decomposition of AgNO3 enlarges the pore volume of the pore size below 3 nm, thus enhancing the total pore volume of Ag-Ce-BTC-C [39]. Fig. 5 shows the SEM images of the CeO2–500 and the supported Ag catalysts. Our previous works [39, 41] had been reported that Ce-BTC displayed the strawsheave shape with a diameter of 25 μm. After calcination at 500 °C, the strawsheave shape is retained in CeO2–500 (Fig. 5(A)). However, after the introduction of Ag NPs, the strawsheave shape is loosed (Fig. 5(B)), which may be ascribed to the second calcination under 30% O2/Ar flow at 500 °C. Fig. 5(C and D) show the SEM images of Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C and Ag-Ce-BTC-IM. It can be found that the strawsheave shape is disappeared, which may be ascribed to the effect of AgNO3 on Ce-BTC. Additionally, no any Ag NPs can be found, which is attributed to the small particles of Ag NPs. To confirm the successfully introduction of Ag NPs, the TEM was used. Fig. 6 shows the TEM images of the supported Ag catalysts. It can be found that the Ag NPs are evenly distribution on CeO2. The particles size of Ag NPs distribution was inserted in Fig. 6 (A-C). The average particle sizes of Ag NPs of Ag/CeO2–500-IM, Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C and Ag-Ce-BTC-C is 5.21, 8.43 and 5.15 nm. Fig. 6(D) shows the HR-TEM of Ag-Ce-BTC-C. The HR-TEM exhibits the lattice spacing of 0.236 and 0.312 nm, corresponding to the (111) lattice planes of Ag NPs and CeO2, respectively. The existence of Ag NPs confirms the successfully loading of Ag NPs. The UV–vis DRS was usually used to determine the specific state of supported Ag catalysts [45,46]. Generally, the absorbance bands at 215 and 235 nm was ascribed to the 4d10–4d95s1 electron transition of Ag+ ions [47,48]. The peak at about 275 nm was the characteristic absorbance peak of Ag cluster [49,50]. The peak at about 410 is attributed to the surface plasma resonance of Ag NPs [45,51]. Fig. 7 shows the UV–vis DRS spectra of CeO2–500 and the supported Ag catalysts. Compared with CeO2–500, three new absorbance bands at 278 and 417 nm are appeared in the supported Ag catalysts. No obvious absorbance peak appeared at 215 or 235 nm, indicating the absence of Ag+ in the supported catalysts. According to the above analysis, the absorbance peak at 278 nm was ascribed to Ag cluster. The band at 417 nm is attributed to the existence of Ag NPs. All of these indicated that the Ag NPs were successfully loaded on the supported Ag catalysts. This is consistent with the XRD and TEM results. To investigate the redox properties and the surface reducibility of CeO2–500 and the supported Ag catalysts, the H2-TPR was carried out. The H2-TPR profiles are displayed in Fig. 8 . For CeO2–500, only one broad peak can be found. The broad peak at 544 °C was attributed surface oxygen and the reduction of surface Ce4+ to Ce3+ [52,53]. After the introduction of Ag NPs, new peaks appeared at 100–320 °C. This is attributed to the fact that nano-silver facilely dissociates H2 molecules and then the H atoms may spill onto Ag or ceria to react with the O [52]. The peak at about 150 °C was ascribed to the surface chemical absorbed oxygen species [29]. The peak at 250 °C is attributed to O2− in surface oxygen vacancies near and far from the Ag NPs [52]. After impregnation of Ag, H2 dissociates and reacts with absorbed oxygen absorbed on surface oxygen vacancies [52]. In addition, Ag NPs could improve the reducibility of surface oxygen of CeO2 by weakening the Ce-O bonds adjacent to Ag species [53,54]. Compared with CeO2–500, the peak ascribed to the reduction of surface Ce4+ to Ce3+ was shift to a lower temperature, indicating the introduction of Ag NPs can improve the reduction ability of CeO2. To further determine the reducibility of the three supported Ag catalysts, the consumption of H2 between 100 and 320 °C, and the results are listed in Table 1. According to above analysis, the H2 consumption between 100 and 320 °C is proportional to the content of chemical adsorbed oxygen species (active oxygen species) on the surface and the reduction ability of the catalyst. It can be found that the H2 consumption of the three supported Ag catalysts ranked as Ag-Ce-BTC-C > Ag/CeO2-IM > Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C, indicating that the Ag-Ce-BTC-C possesses the largest active oxygen species and better reduction ability. To determine the surface chemical composite and state of the supported Ag catalysts, the XPS was performed. Fig. 9 shows the XPS full spectra and high-resolution spectra of the three supported catalysts. It can be found from Fig. 9(A) that the peaks of Ce 3d, O 1 s, C 1 s and Ag 3d can be found. The appearance of Ag 3d indicated the successfully introduction of Ag NPs. Fig. 9(B) shows the O 1 s spectrum, which was divided into three peaks. The peaks at 529.2, 531.3 and 533.0 eV were attributed to the lattice oxygen (Olat) species, surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads) species and the surface OH (OOH) species, respectively [55–58]. The molar ratios of Oads to Olat are summarized in Table 2 . The Oads/Olat values of Ag/CeO2-IM, Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C and Ag-Ce-BTC-C are 0.250, 0.252 and 0.290, respectively. Generally, the Oads species are produced by adsorbing and activating oxygen molecules by surface oxygen vacancies [59,60]. A higher molar ratio of Oads/Olat indicates more oxygen vacancies and active oxygen species [61]. The Ag-Ce-BTC-C possesses the highest Oads/Olat molar ratio of 0.290, indicating that there are more oxygen vacancies and active oxygen species in Ag-Ce-BTC-C. This is consistent with the H2-TPR results. Fig. 9(C) displays the Ce 3d spectra of the three supported Ag catalysts. Generally, the Ce 3d orbit spectrum can be divided into eight peaks. The peaks of Ce4+ appeared at 882.3, 888.8, 898.4, 900.9, 907.6 and 916.8 eV, corresponding to v, v’’, v’’, u, u’’ and u’’’, respectively [39,40]. The peaks appeared at 884.8 and 903.0 eV corresponded to v’ and u’ of Ce3+, respectively [39,40,62]. It had been reported that the appearance of Ce4+ and Ce3+ 3d orbits is related to Olat species and the surface oxygen vacancies [52,53]. Thus, the molar ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ is calculated to evaluate the concentration of oxygen vacancies on the three supported Ag catalysts. The Ce3+/Ce4+ ratios of the supported Ag catalysts are listed in Table 2. The values for Ag/CeO2-IM, Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C and Ag-Ce-BTC-C were 0.180, 0.165 and 0.182, respectively. Compared with Ag/CeO2-IM and Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C, Ag-Ce-BTC-C possesses the highest Ce3+/Ce4+ value, indicating the more vacancies in Ag-Ce-BTC-C. The Ag 3d spectra of the three supported Ag catalysts are presented in Fig. 9(D), and were fitted to two pairs of double peaks. The peaks at 368.2 and 374.2 eV were assigned to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 orbit of Ag0, respectively [29,63]. The peaks at 367.8 and 373.8 were attributed to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 orbit of Agδ+, respectively [64]. Notably, compared with Ag/CeO2-IM and Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C, the banding energies of Ag0 and Agδ+ were shifted to the lower (Fig. 9(D)), which might be due to the strength interaction between Ce and Ag. It had been reported that silver was unstable in oxygen atmosphere. Thus, the binding energy of silver species did not completely match with AgO and Ag2O [36]. The molar ratio of Ag0/Agδ+ was calculated by the peak area and summarized in Table 2. The Ag0/Agδ+ ratio of Ag/CeO2-IM, Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C and Ag-Ce-BTC-C were 0.311, 0.987 and 1.307, respectively. It can be found that the Ag-Ce-BTC-C has the largest Ag0/Agδ+ ratio. In addition, the surface Ag content (Table 2) of Ag/CeO2-IM, Ag-Ce-BTC-C and Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C were 4.97, 3.42, 10.12 wt%, respectively, which was different from that of ICP-OES results (Table 1). This is because XPS measures surface element content. Additionally, the difference of Ag content measured by XPS and ICP-OES may be related to the synthesis method. For Ag/CeO2-IM and Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C, the wet impregnation method could lead to the uneven distribution of Ag nanoparticles. Furthermore, during the flowing calcination, because Ag/Ce-BTC-IM contained a large amount of carbon, the combustion of carbon in O2/Ar atmosphere would cause the aggregation of Ag particles and led to a more uneven distribution of Ag. It had been reported that highly dispersed Ag NPs could be obtained buy one-pot synthesis [65]. Thus, the Ag NPs were more evenly distributed in Ag-Ce-BTC-C prepared by one-pot synthesis. Additionally, the Ag NPs average particle size of Ag/CeO2-IM (5.21 nm), Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C (8.43 nm) and Ag-Ce-BTC-C (5.15 nm) calculated by TEM could also confirm this result. 3.2 The effect of synthesis methods For these three supported Ag catalysts, it could be found from SEM (Fig. 5) that the synthesis methods greatly influenced their morphology. In addition, due to the different carbon content of the catalyst during the calcination process, the particle size of the formed Ag NPs (Fig. 6(B-D)) was different. For Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C, the combustion of carbon will cause the grain size of CeO2 to increase (Table 1), thereby reducing its specific surface area and affecting its properties and chemical composition. However, for Ag-Ce-BTC-C, in the high-temperature hydrothermal process, the distribution of Ce and Ag is more uniform and may interact with each other (Fig. 9(D)). Then during calcination, the interaction between Ce and Ag makes the CeO2 grain size smaller, the reduction of the catalyst, and the increase of the surface Oads, Ce3+, Ag° content. 3.3 Catalytic performance To evaluate the catalytic performance of these catalysts, toluene was selected. Fig. 10 (A) illustrates the temperature-dependent toluene conversion. Generally, the temperatures of toluene conversion at 10%, 50% and 90% (T10, T50 and T90) are used to estimate the catalytic performance of a catalyst. The T10, T50 and T90 of CeO2–500 and the three supported Ag catalysts are summarized in Table 1. The T90 of CeO2–500, Ag/CeO2-IM, Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C and Ag-Ce-BTC-C are 252, 235, 242 and 226 °C, respectively. Compared with CeO2–500, toluene conversion over the three supported Ag catalysts was enhanced in different degrees. Among them, Ag-Ce-BTC-C presents the best catalytic performance. In addition, compared with other supported Ag catalysts [66–70], the Ag-Ce-BTC-C prepared in this work exhibited better catalytic performance. The active energy of CeO2–500 and the supported Ag catalysts was calculated according to Arrhenius formula. Fig. 10(B) shows the Arrhenius plots and the active energies of the samples are summarized in Table 1. The active energies of CeO2–500, A/CeO2-IM, Ag/Ce-BTC-IM-C and Ag-Ce-BTC-C were 148.98, 91.78, 102.20 and 63.11 kJ/mol. Compared with other supported Ag catalysts, the active energy value of Ag-Ce-BTC-C was smallest, indicating that Ag-Ce-BTC-C possesses the best catalytic performance for toluene oxidation. Generally, the catalytic activity of a catalyst is closely related to its reduction ability, active oxygen species, the concentration of oxygen vacancies and surface chemical composition [39,40]. According to the analysis of above characterization and catalytic performance results, it can be found that the different preparation methods had a great influence on the reduction ability, active species and surface chemical composition of the supported Ag catalysts (Scheme 1(B-D)), which further influence their catalytic activity. It had been reported that the surface active oxygen species, surface oxygen vacancies and better reduction ability can participate in the chemical adsorption of toluene and facilitate the degradation of toluene [60]. The H2-TPR results (Fig. 8 and Table 1) indicated that the Ag-Ce-BTC-C possesses the largest active oxygen species and better reduction ability, promoting the degradation of toluene. In addition, the results of O 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 9(B) and Table 2) displayed that Ag-Ce-BTC-C possesses largest Oads species. And the Oads species is generated by surface oxygen vacancies [60]. The more oxygen adsorbed, the higher oxygen vacancies concentration, the better catalytic activity of the catalyst. Furthermore, for CeO2, the larger the molar ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ indicates that there are more oxygen vacancies in the catalysts. From Fig. 9(C) and Table 2, it can be found that the Ag-Ce-BTC-C has the largest molar ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ (0.182), indicating that there are more oxygen vacancies in Ag-Ce-BTC-C, further confirming the better catalytic performance of Ag-Ce-BTC-C for toluene oxidation. As well know, the state of silver strongly affects the adsorption of oxygen and further influences the catalytic performance of a catalyst [71]. And the Ag0 play an important role for catalytic oxidation [36,49]. In this work, Ag-Ce-BTC-C exhibits the largest Ag0/Agδ+ molar ratio, which account for its better catalytic activity. To sum up, the better catalytic performance of Ag-Ce-BTC-C was attributed to the better reduction ability, more active oxygen species, more oxygen vacancies and high molar ratio of Oads/Olat, Ce3+/Ce4+ and Ag0/Agδ+. Table 3 To learn the water resistance, effect of WSHV, reusability and stability of the catalysts, Ag-Ce-BTC-C was selected. Fig. 11 (A) presents the effect of 5.0 vol.% water vapor at 225 °C for toluene over Ag-Ce-BTC-C. It can be found that when the introduction of water vapor, the toluene conversion was decreased for about 12%. When cut off the water vapor, the conversion of toluene recovered gradually. The decrease of toluene conversion might be due to the competitive adsorption between toluene and water vapor [39]. Fig. 11(B-D) display the effect of WSHV, reusability and stability of Ag-Ce-BTC-C. It can be found that the WSHV could influence the catalytic performance of Ag-Ce-BTC-C. And Ag-Ce-BTC-C exhibited good reusability and stability. To further confirm the good stability and reusability, the XRD was used to measure the crystal structure of Ag-Ce-BTC-C after toluene oxidation. As shown in Fig. 12 , compared with fresh Ag-Ce-BTC-C, the XRD pattern of Ag-Ce-BTC-C after toluene oxidation had no change, which also confirmed the great stability of Ag-Ce-BTC-C. 4 Conclusion In summary, MOF-derived CeO2 supported Ag catalysts were prepared by different synthesis methods. A series of characterization and experimental results exhibited that the preparation methods had a great influence on the reduction ability, active oxygen species, the concentration of oxygen vacancies and surface chemical composition of the supported Ag catalysts and further affected the catalytic performance for toluene. Among the three supported Ag catalyst, the Ag-Ce-BTC-C prepared by one-pot synthesis and calcination exhibited the best catalytic performance for toluene oxidation. H2-TPR and XPS results indicated that the better catalytic performance of Ag-Ce-BTC-C was attributed to the better reduction ability, more active species, more concentration of oxygen vacancies and the larger molar ratio of Oads/Olat, Ce3+/Ce4+ and Ag0/Agδ+. This work has a certain guiding significance for the preparation of highly active MOF-derived supported catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs), such as toluene, have aroused wide concerns its emissions growth and harmfulness. Catalytic oxidation has been considered as one of the most efficient technologies for toluene degradation. In this work, MOF-derived CeO2 supported Ag catalysts were prepared by different synthesis method. Toluene oxidation test found that Ag-Ce-BTC-C synthesized by one-pot and calcination at 500 °C under Ar and O2 atmosphere exhibited the better catalytic performance for toluene oxidation (T90 = 226 °C). H2 temperature programmed reduction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic results exhibited that the preparation method had a great influence on the physicochemical properties of the supported Ag catalysts. The better catalytic performance was attributed to the better reducibility, more active oxygen species and oxygen vacancies, higher molar ratio of Oads/Olat, Ce3+/Ce4+ and Ag0/Agδ+. This work has a certain guiding significance for the preparation of highly active MOF-derived supported catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: MOF-derived CeO2 supported Ag catalysts for toluene oxidation: The effect of synthesis method
